item.title: Grading
item.description: The grading will happen twice per year. Dan grading will be done once per year with the help of Stefan Stenudd. The grades will be Aikikai grades. Requirements/Techniques per Grade coming soon

item.title: Contact
item.description: Email address We'll never share your email with anyone else. Subject Message Submit × Yes, the contact form works. I'll get an email, when you press Send. Please don't spam me!

item.title: Impressum
item.description: site author: Stephan Schroeder 55 St. Augustines Rd NW1 9RR London UK

item.title: Privacy Notice
item.description: No cookies, no tracking and no data is created/saved for future marketing. The contact message is send via AWS Lambda, but no data is retained (or even logs created), apart from the email in the dojos inbox, which is deleted after it has been answered.

Data by OpenStreetMap, under ODbL. 42 Made Up Rd N0W ERE London Price first class is free x$ per week y$ per month Schedule Tuesday19:30-20:30 Thursday19:30-20:30 Saturday10:00-12:00 Opening Soon! Late 2019 or early 2020. If you have questions feel free to use the contact form

item.title: Teachers
item.description: Stephan Schroeder: 3rd Dan Aikikai started with Aikido in 2003 while still at university and never stopped. After finishing the university, he moved to Berlin where he continued his training in a dojo that was affiliated with Watanabe Nobuyuki, 8 Dan, (†2018) who’s seminars Stephan visited for many years. The thing with Watanabe Sensei was that you probably didn’t end up concrete answers but with very interesting questions. Around 2010 Stephan started visiting the seminars of Stefan Stenudd, by now 7 Dan, who Stephan got interested in after seeing one of his YouTube videos.

Stefan Stenudd: 7th Dan Aikikai, 4th Dan Iaido Stefan Stenudd is an artist in many ways, a natuaral leader and gets easily bored. Yet after more that 40 years of Aikido he has yet to become bored by his own Aikido. It’s easy to assume that one got an idea of what Stefan’s Aikido looks like, but prolonged exposure will reveal its wide range and depth. This might partly be explained by a concious effort to avoid one of the trappings of being a teacher: to only teach that which you consider yourself to be “good” in.
